item.title: Windows VS Linux
item.dc:creator: @DeadBird DeadBird
item.description:
@DeadBird wrote:

[quote=“Alex Owns, post:40, topic:18999”]Take the viruses out of the equation and what is better about Linux? I mean, cmon folks…if you get a virus on your computer, you’re a dumbass!

It’s called anti-virus software. Get it from a torrent.[/quote]
How does one get anti-virus while setting up an original Windows XP (neither service packs) to prevent themselves from getting a sasser\blaster worm?
You can’t. Thats just sad that on a version of Windows, you can get attacked while installing.

Read full topic

item.title: Windows VS Linux

item.description:
@Zach1188 wrote:

[quote=“Alex Owns, post:40, topic:18999”]Take the viruses out of the equation and what is better about Linux? I mean, cmon folks…if you get a virus on your computer, you’re a dumbass!

It’s called anti-virus software. Get it from a torrent.[/quote]

  1. The beauty of it is you shouldn’t have to worry about viruses in any way.

  2. Other than the virus issue, Linux is still IMO better than Windows. I’m not really sure why I think that, but once you get used to Linux you will start to dislike Windows.

item.title: Windows VS Linux
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Alex Owns:

Take the viruses out of the equation and what is better about Linux?

Take the large amount of open source software, including the kernel itself and all related utilities. The large amount of people working towards a common goal - the community support. A decent shell/command-line. No corporate wankery in the form of Microsoft. Linux is not just an Operating System, it’s a way of life. Reasons? There are no reasons… but who needs reasons when you’ve got BASH?

Read full topic

item.title: Windows VS Linux
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

pkedpker:

making linux open source is the most stupidist thing ever hackers look at source code to find buffer overflows to do remote exploits bind netcat shells on your pc and formating ur pc.

Apart from the obvious fact that if Linux wasn’t open source, it almost certainly wouldn’t be where it is today, did it ever occur to you that this also means the bugs are being fixed by hundreds of thousands of developers all over the world? There are community like this one, but instead of being dedicated to hacking a game, they “hack” the bugs out of open source software. A lot better than Microsoft’s bug releases, which tend to happen a month late, and then don’t fix the bug completely and so on and so on.

Read full topic

“Panda Antivirus for Linux is an antivirus for Linux servers and desktops.”

item.title: Windows VS Linux
item.dc:creator: @Zach1188 Zach1188
item.description:
@Zach1188 wrote:

Three things:

The only real issue with the kernel being out of date is if you are still using the 2.4.x kernel, which no one would do unless they had a valid reason for it. If someone does find an exploit, it wont affect all Linux users.

Second, Linux antivirus programs are made for Linux-based mail servers to prevent distribution of viruses through email, not for the Linux OS itself.

Third, I was not comparing any specific distro to Windows, just Linux in general (hence “Windows vs Linux”, not “Windows vs FreeBSD”).

Read full topic

item.title: Windows VS Linux
item.dc:creator: @juju juju
item.description:
@juju wrote:

40 Linux viruses just does not sound right. Why would antivirus companies bother to make Linux antivirus programs if there are only 40 viruses for the OS? I do acknowledge that Linux is much, much more secure than Windows.

Also, if you’re going to compare Linux security against Windows, why not compare OpenBSD or FreeBSD against Linux?
“Only one remote hole in the default install, in more than 10 years!”

Read full topic

item.title: Windows VS Linux
item.dc:creator: @Zach1188 Zach1188
item.description:
@Zach1188 wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:28, topic:18999”]“Perhaps”.

I would guess the number is significantly higher.[/quote]
Fine, lets exagerate a bit. Say there are 300 viruses for Linux, which I guarantee there is not this many (I am not including spyware!). I know none of them are widespread, since Linux is a “do it how you want it” type of OS. In Windows, pretty much everyone is the same, so a good virus will pretty much fuck over everyone, and spread like crazy. With Linux, no one has an identical setup, so a virus that would work on you will most likely not work with the guy next door (unless he has the same distro etc.). And even if it does work on him, all it can do is kill his personal files. It (for the most part) wont harm the system itself in any way, shape, or form (unless you’re an idiot who installs all your apps in your personal folder).

And about the whole “perhaps” thing. That site said there are more then most sites say there are. Most of the other sites I saw said there were only 20, so I suppose you could guess there are around 100 viruses tops, which is still significantly lower than Windows.

Read full topic

item.title: Windows VS Linux
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

“Perhaps”.

I would guess the number is significantly higher.

Read full topic

item.title: Windows VS Linux
item.dc:creator: @Zach1188 Zach1188
item.description:
@Zach1188 wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:26, topic:18999”][quote author=Zach1188 link=topic=28832.msg551832#msg551832 date=1164950391]

  • Windows has about 60,000 viruses total. Linux has less than 40 viruses, none of which are widespread.

lol.

Lol? It’s true.
[/quote]

Post your source.[/quote]
Ok, then. http://www.theregister.co.uk/2003/10/06/linux_vs_windows_viruses/

Heres a direct quote from the website:

Sure, there are Linux viruses. But let's compare the numbers. According to Dr. Nic Peeling and Dr Julian Satchell's Analysis of the Impact of Open Source Software (note: the link is to a 135 kb PDF file):

“There are about 60,000 viruses known for Windows, 40 or so for the Macintosh, about 5 for commercial Unix versions, and perhaps 40 for Linux. Most of the Windows viruses are not important, but many hundreds have caused widespread damage. Two or three of the Macintosh viruses were widespread enough to be of importance. None of the Unix or Linux viruses became widespread - most were confined to the laboratory.”

So there are far fewer viruses for Mac OS X and Linux. It’s true that those two operating systems do not have monopoly numbers, though in some industries they have substantial numbers of users. But even if Linux becomes the dominant desktop computing platform, and Mac OS X continues its growth in businesses and homes, these Unix-based OS’s will never experience all of the problems we’re seeing now with email-borne viruses and worms in the Microsoft world. Why?

Read full topic
